text: Rain. Christmas lights. A rusted out '56 Lincoln rattles  down the bleak boulevard. In it: JOE STEVENS, an angry, b man in his late 20's, beside him his 10-year-old son, JOE JR. Joe Jr. stares out the window at passing: boarded buildin whores with raincoats over their heads trying to flag dow john, a black Santa, a knot of drinkers. Breaking the sil
Your mother okay?
Yes, sir.
They stop at a light. Joe Stevens tries to furtively snor little something. He spots Joe Jr. watching.
(firm, without irony) Don't you do this shit, boy. Don't  you ever fuckin' touch it, you hear  me?
Joe Jr. stares, silent; Joe Jr.'s about to hit him.
(continuing) You hear me, goddam it?
The boy nods. Satisfied, Joe Sr. draws in the stuff. It m him feel good, strong, worried and determined all at once
(continuing; charged  up) What do you want for Christmas?
I don't know.
(light changes; he  accelerates) You don't know?? You gotta know what  you want, boy, if you ever expect to  get it.
A sudden charm to his bravado. Joe Jr. smiles uncertainly Joe Sr. grins back, pulls up in front of a liquor store.
(continuing) Wait here. This won't take a minute.

Joe Jr. doesn't notice or doesn't remark that his father, just before entering the store, draws a handgun from bene his coat. The boy gazes dreamily at the street. The lunatic Black S marches by, ranting to himself ("Then the white man say.. The RAIN HAMMERS on the roof and windshield. Joe Jr. brea on the glass, fogging the scene. From the store: MUFFLED GUNFIRE. Joe Jr. looks that way. Another GUNSHOT, then: His father comes out the door clutching money in one hand He strides toward the car with a reckless pride. He doesn notice: The liquor store door opens behind him. A SHOTGUN BLAST. Joe Stevens' guts splatter onto the car  windshield. A look of terrible amazement; he sinks to his knees.
Daddy!!
He jumps from the car, kneels by his father. The STORE OWNER (47, Slavic) drags the gun toward them,  bleeding profusely.
(enraged, almost to  tears) Fuckin' niggers... fuckin' niggers...
looks at the money in his hand: two 20's, two 5's.
Fifty bucks... fifty goddam bucks. (looks up at his son) I'm sorry...
He stuffs the blood-soaked bills in the boy's shirt pocke and dies. Joe Jr. looks up at...
Bloody, nearly unconscious, he aims the shotgun at the bo who is too frightened to move.
Please, Mister...

The man dies on his feet. As he falls backward, he pulls trigger, the BLAST shattering the car windows. Cop cars SQUEAL up. Uniformed cops leap out, guns drawn,  survey the scene. Then one notices Joe Jr., staring motio at his father and the store owner, dead together. ON HIS
-- but older, harder, colder. They're concentrating on a  paper before him.
Hundreds of TRUE/FALSE questions... 1.) I have never indulged in any unusual sexual practices (T/F)

2.) I have often felt that strangers were looking at me  critically. (T/F) 3.) When I was young I occasionally stole things. (T/F) Joe Stevens marks these TRUE, FALSE, FALSE then comes to: 4.) A person's station in life is at least partially  determined by his race. (T/F) We are:

Thirty-seven Black Cleveland police officers (many in uni including Joe) are taking the MMPI. Some roll their eyes the questions. Some try to copy answers. Others, like Joe work with rapid concentration. But he gets stuck on #4. Marks it false. Erases it. Marks true. Erases that. Ponders. Goes on to: #5. At times I he so well it bothers me. (T/F) He marks that true.
GERALD CARVER, 36, an ambitious government lawyer with a  relaxed, vaguely hip manner, looks over the file of the  ingratiating BLACK OFFICER sitting across the desk from h
Officer Leland? You know the  difference between a black man and  nigger?
Leland is startled, insulted, but doesn't want to blow th interview. He smiles weakly, shakes his head no.
(continuing; pleasant  smile) Yeah, most niggers don't.
Stung, Leland tries to laugh. Carver puts his file aside, picks up another.
(continuing) Nice to meet you.
A SECOND BLACK OFFICER is powerfully built, politically  conscious, takes no shit. Carver's leafing through his fi
So, Winston, what's the difference  between a black man and a nigger?
Winston is out of his chair before the question is finish drags Carver by the shirt front halfway across the desk a hisses into his face:
Who the fuck do you think you're  talking to?
Carver smiles cheerfully past Winston's cocked fist.
Thanks for coming in.
Nonplussed by this cool dismissal, Winston stalks out. Ca picks up the next file, unfazed.
Joe Stevens watches Carver reading his file and waiting f an answer. When none is forthcoming, Carver glances up, f Stevens looking right back at him.
The nigger's the one who falls for  your bullshit.
He says it pleasantly, without belligerence. Carver smile he's found his man. He offers his hand.
Gerald Carver, United States District  Attorney. Call me Gerry.

ON A TV SCREEN: a grainy black-and-white tape, date and t stamped at the bottom. A grungy street, palm trees. The l from the monitor dimly illuminates Carver and Stevens. On SCREEN the CAMERA finds: A MAN in jeans, sneakers and  sweatshirt on a street corner.
He ought to be wearing a sign.
You can tell he's a cop?

Stevens laughs: it's obvious. A real DRUG DEALER joins the cop. UNDERCOVER COP: "You go it?" DEALER: "In the motel, right over here..." The Cop's uneasy, keeps glancing back toward the CAMERA as they go.
He keeps looking for his back-up.  Now, the other guy knows it, too.
Then why's he taking him to the room?
(why else?) To rip him off.

Carver studies Stevens in the darkness, impressed. ON SCREEN: The figures disappear into the motel. We hear  their voices. DEALER: "Here, try some of it." UNDERCOVER  COP: "Uhh... No, I don't..." DEALER: "Why not, you  sonofabitch?" Two bursts of SOUND DISTORTION. A plainclothes cop, TAFT, (black, stocky, powerful) bolts from behind the CAMERA, sprints toward the motel. The CAM wobbles after him.
(continuing) Too late.
ON SCREEN: The CAMERA (jerky, hand-held) nears the open m door. Taft is bent over the Undercover Cop's body.
Oh, Bobby... Jesus, Jesus... (to the CAMERA) Get an ambulance -- and back up.  Now!
He slams the wall, starts past the CAMERA. Carver pushes pause button; the tape freezes on a jerky image of Taft's face.
(focussed on Taft) Who is he?
Charles Taft. LAPD Narcotics.
He's a good cop.
He's a great cop. Two [names citation]  and a [another citation]. As tough  as they come and twice as honest.
Carver watches Stevens watch Taft, smiles at something.
But the cops aren't getting it done  here, are they? Gotta try something  new...
He opens a manila envelope, dumps the contents on the des driver's license, social security card, high school  transcript, prison records... all in the name of William Hull. No photos.
(continuing) Who's John Hull?

You are. If you want to be. (off Stevens) Most undercover guys don't know what  they're doing because it's a day  gig. (indicates dead cop  on TV) I need somebody who goes under and  stays there; six months, a year,  five years...
What does he have to do?
Buy drugs. Sell drugs. Feed me  information.
He's a snitch.

He's a drug dealer. A criminal. A  scumbag. But for the right side. (beat) I want you to come to Los Angeles on  loan to the Justice Department as a  federal agent. Your experience there  will be credited toward your seniority  here. And you'll come back to  Cleveland a P3 or higher.
(uncomfortable) I can't do that. I've got a wife and  kids.
You're separated from your wife,  she's filled for divorce. You see  your kids every other weekend.
Stevens takes a breath: this is awkward to explain.
(almost a confession) All my life I've stayed away from  that stuff. I've never touched drugs.
(tolerant) Come on, a little grass...?
Not grass. Not nothing. I never even  had a drink. (his motto) Never have, never will. You don't  understand. I made a choice in my  life.

What's to understand? You saw your  father killed when you were ten, and  you decided you wouldn't be like  that. (off Stevens' surprise,  Carver grins) I'm God, I know everything. You wanted  to be a good boy, so you became a  cop. Hiding out in uniform... That's  why you got the hard-on for Taft.
It's not that simple.
(opening Joe's file;  as if reluctantly) I'll tell the truth, Joe. You're  never going to be a Taft.
I don't believe that.
But he does.
(looks at MMPI results) You ever take a look at your  psychological profile? You score  almost like a criminal. (reading) "Resents authority..."
I do not.
"...Exaggerated moral standards, but  with no underlying value system."  Look at the anger, the repressed  violence, it's almost off the scale...
Let me see that...
Carver hands him the scores which are, of course, just  clusters of numbers. Stevens is upset, though oddly  unsurprised, as if this only confirmed his secret fears.
Why'd you join the force?
(awkward, but felt) I wanted to be of use.

Well, now you can be. You won't be  Taft, but maybe you'll be something  more... interesting. (sits back) There's a man named Ramon Gallegos  who supplies 60% of the cocaine to  the West Coast. He's smart, smooth,  and sufficiently elusive that we  don't even have an adult photograph  of him. However, his uncle is Hector  Guzman, an important Latin American  political figure. Gallegos uses  Uncle's connections to get product  into the country, and everyone we've  sent after him has ended up like  that...
Indicates dead body on TV.
Why would I be different?

You already are, that's the point... (indicates file, test  scores) You've got the ability and the  personality to go underground and  blend in completely. That's what the  others couldn't. Some part of them  showed. That's why they're dead.  See, there's only one rule in this  game.
Stevens raises his eyebrows: what?
(continuing) Don't blow your cover.
Stevens parks outside a small, well-maintained house. As gets out, he spots a GROUP OF KIDS (black and Hispanic)  playing down the street. He's not pleased about that.
(calls to them) Joe-J, Carmen...
A BOY, 7, and a GIRL, 5, (both light-skinned) run to him  shouting, "Daddy," jump into his arms, competing for  attention, as if they haven't seen him in ages.
What were you doing with those kids?
Playing...
(displeased) Your mom lets you play with them?
Yes, sir... Yes, sir.

His strictness has already sobered their enthusiasm. Sens this, he attempts to embrace them which he can do only  awkwardly. Meanwhile, his wife, TERRY (Southern white) has come out screen door. She and Stevens bristle at each other.
I thought we talked about this. The  older brother up there's got a sheet  with --
Lay off it. They're just kids...
Both are ready to fight, but restrain themselves. A big  Polynesian, TITO comes out the door.
Hey, Joe.
Tito...
A moment of surprise, then he gets it. He looks to Terry. She gives a little shrug, refusing to be embarrassed.
Stevens is trying to seem interested in Carmen's little  drawings.
They're real nice, honey. Is that a  horse?
(exasperated) Daddy! It's a bunny...
She puts her arms around him.
(continuing) I don't want you to go away, Daddy.
It's my work. I've got to.
Over her shoulder he sees Terry sitting with a subdued Jo J. Her face seems to say, "See, I told you..." Avoiding t accusation, Stevens notices a bruise on Carmen's arm.
(continuing) What happened to you there, baby?
Tito did it.
(instantly outraged) He hit you?! (up in a fury) God damn it, what's he doing touching  her? I'm gonna...
Terry intercepts him on his way out of the room.
She was running behind his chair  when he got up. It was an accident. (he's uncertain) A complete... total... accident.
Stevens looks at Carmen who giggles. He's humiliated by h own temper, attempts to calm himself. Terry puts a sympat hand on his shoulder.
The immense sprawl, the arterial flow of the freeways, th blinding light. We DESCEND...
People getting off, among them the former Joe Stevens, no known as JOHN HULL. He's carrying a suitcase.
Hull goes up the stairs onto a downtown street.

South L.A. neighborhood. A 13-year-old BLACK YOUTH sellin drugs through a car window. Hull walks by. He's at ease,  looking around, his manner subtly announcing that he belo here, just as in the train station he seemed to belong am the commuters.
A fat BLONDE WOMAN (61, large white glasses, tiny shoes)  leads Hull down a corridor.
Television mostly. I was on "Sky  King" twice, "Ramar of the Jungle."  That was a silly show. The jungle  was mostly flats...

They pass an open door where a 6-year-old boy, JAMES, a  latchkey, sits on the stoop playing Gameboy; inside, his  mother, BELINDA, a broken down whore, is doing her nails drinking Pepsi. She looks up, bats her lashes at Hull.
(continuing) You want my advice, I'd stay away  from that bitch.
She opens the door to the room across the hall. A dump. H walks in, drops his duffle: he'll take it. The Blonde lou in the doorway. He closes the door.

Hull empties his pockets on the dresser. Looks at his mon room key, identification. Looks at himself in the mirror. touches his clothes, his face, tries on different express (NOTE: Throughout the film, Hull continually checks himse out in mirrors, both to adjust his appearance to the  circumstances and as if in an attempt to recall who he  "really" is.)
On the seam between South-Central and USC. Lots of people out: children, students, dealers, whores. Hull with a new haircut.
Dealers (most in mid-teens) meeting cars, making transact All this casually observed. EDDIE comes up the street,  reciting his version of an old street toast.
On the day of the King's castration,  all the counts and no accounts were  down on the deck with Georgia Tech  taking turns in the back seat...

Those dealers not at car windows, gather around. He never speaks to them, goes on declaiming as he exchanges drugs money. Hull watches, talking to another street person. His appea continues to change: clothes, posture, walk, gestures sub conform to the environment, a bit like Zelig. Throughout film his appearance shifts, depending on who he's with. W always recognize him, but each time he's different. He walks up to a dealer, makes a quick buy and keeps goin But he sees them and is seen.
Hull drops eleven foil balls on a green blotter. Carver c out money for him.
He sits at the window, eating a burrito, watching little  James play in the courtyard.
Hull approaches another Dealer, the 13-year-old seen earl (angelic face). Like Hull, he's trying to act tough.
Whatta you got?
(voice just changing) Nickel rock, dime rock. Excellent  shit.
Hull exchanges a folded twenty for two foil balls. He wal off. He has gone twenty feet when...
SQUEALS to a stop opposite the Dealer. A huge young black man, IVY (23, all in red with a red  headband), leans out the passenger window, shouting at th 13-year-old.
What the fuck I tell you about being  here?
Everyone turns to look, but Hull's view is blocked.
No, wait...
Too fuckin' late.
POPPING noises. Ivy is waving an automatic weapon. Everyo on the street but Hull has hit the ground.
(enjoying it, shouting) Get down, motherfuckers!
Ivy laughs and fondles a girlfriend as the car ROARS off. sees Hull, pretends to fire, laughs as Hull, too, ducks.  When Ivy's gone, he runs to where a CROWD has gathered  around...

lying in the street, a bullet hole in his head, eyes open He twitches and kicks, blood pulsing from the neat wound. Then he's dead. The faces around him (young, old, many ra watch with a variety of emotions.
Who is he?... Why'd they shoot him?...  Ivy did him, man... He's in the wrong  fuckin' place... That poor boy...  Get his beeper...

Cops push through to the body. As the crowd disperses, Hu can't take his eyes off the boy. When he finally does, he sees Eddie, drink in hand. Their eyes meet, and Eddie, a  rapper, raises his eyebrows in brief acknowledgment of so
(sadly) He done done, ain't he?
A bar with a neon bird for a sign. Hull enters.
A racial mix. Hull takes a seat at the bar. Stuffed birds line the lintel above the bottles. A female BARTENDER (lo red nails) greets him familiarly.
How's it going, John?
I'm in there.

Without being asked, she sets him up a Dry Sack with a lo red straw. (NOTE: He never touches the drink.) Hull's  appearance has continued to change. His clothes have beco flashier, he has an earring, the start of a goatee. Eddie approaches the bar compulsively reciting one of his toasts.

(to himself) "Where's the Queen," said the King.  "She's in bed with laryngitis." "Is  that bastard still in town?... Fuck  the Queen," said the King, and ten  thousand knights straaaained at their  utmost... (to the bartender) Pina colada times two and a white  wine.
He goes on muttering under his breath, tapping his foot l any crankhead. He notices Hull, greets him as someone he  can't place but knows he's seen around.
(continuing) How you doin', Dudley...
Tries to remember name.
John.
John, man, right...
Clasp hands. Eddie takes his drinks, carries them to...

where he rejoins a white man, DAVID ELIAS (30s, slick,  powerful) and a well-dressed BLACK WOMAN (mid-20s, good- looking). She gets the wine. Elias rises to let her out. As the woman passes Hull on h way to the restrooms, their eyes meet: an instant of perf chemistry. He's struck. Her features open, grow sensual f a moment, but then, as if seeing something she doesn't li her eyes flick away, and she walks by as if he weren't th

(NOTE: Hull invariably meets Carver in this anonymous roo distinguished only by the green blotter and a view of the city. This simple regularity suggest visits to a psychiat Carver probing, testing, teasing, trying to draw Hull out And they feel like therapy, at once a respite and a torme More foil balls on the blotter beside boxes of 3x5  photographs. Photos of Eddie and David Elias are up on a  corkboard, the beginning of a pyramid.

Eddie something... a motormouth...  he supplies the street dealers...  buys from him... (reads name on back  of photo) David Elias... who apparently buys  from a guy named Barbolla or  something. But I haven't seen him.
Carver produces a photo of a handsome Latin in his 50s, p it on the board above Elias.
Barbosa, Felix.
There was also a woman, but she's  not here. (as Carver reaches in  a drawer) I saw a kid killed. Twelve, thirteen  at the most. Turf war.
Carver shrugs: these things happen. He hands Hull a lot o cash, much more than expected. Hull does understand.
Get to Elias. Then to Barbosa.
You can't rush this stuff.
Rush it, please. I want art, John,  not reality. Budget hearings start  in April, and I need Gallegos by  then. They won't give us funding for  three ounce buys.
We're not just doing this for the  funding, are we?
Without funding, we aren't doing it  at all.

Virtual darkness save splinters of light between the curt Pipes burn here and there in the gloom. Ten or fifteen  crackheads huddle around a battery-operated TV on which T Brokaw is narrating an NBC documentary on drugs. A 12-yea old sits against a wall too stoned even for television. Hull approaches Eddie, regally installed on an automobile bench seat-cum-sofa, a lit pipe in one hand. We barely no the redhead kneeling between his legs, face buried in his crotch. He greets Hull from wrecked bliss. They know each other now.
My man, Dudley, he's so fud-ley...
Hull greets Eddie, some of the others, drops familiarly o an adjacent auto seat. The patrons are making fun of Brok laughing, exchanging fives.
Eddie, man, I need...
Eddie holds up a hand telling Hull to wait. His mind is  elsewhere. His features contract in brief concentration.
Whatever happened to that Drug Czar  motherfucker?... He gave up 'cause  he finally realized he didn't know  nothing about any of that shit...

More laughter, etc. Eddie's concentration peaks, breaks o into a sigh and a smile. Eddie sings a satisfied little song... The redhead rises from Eddie's crotch, and we see it's a  boy, seventeen going on death; he might have been pretty year ago. Eddie passes him the crack pipe, lets him suck greedily f a few seconds before ripping it out of his scabrous mouth and offering it to Hull, who, with a grimace that gets la declines. The others continue to watch and comment on the speech.
So what is it you need so bad, blood?  Need, need, need??
A whole K, quick as you can get it.
(impressed, a trace  of envy) Comin' in the world, Dudley.
(winning grin) All because of my man...
Eddie likes that, holds out a hand. Hull hits it.
Give me a day.
Hull nods, rises.
(continuing) Stick around, let the bitch Hoover  you, too.
Indicating redhead. In all these scenes, Hull acts indifferent to the horror, but here the effort costs him. He masters his disgust wit joke.
Only if you Clorox him first.
Everyone laughs, even the boy.
Eddie comes out the back door of a building, is immediate collared by Taft (the cop on the videotape). He's in his 40s, stocky, balding.
(cheerful, gregarious) Eddie Shitface! Where you been, boy?
Eddie breaks free, runs three feet before HERNANDEZ (a  muscular Mexican) knees him in the groin. Eddie crumples.
(continuing) Eddie, I don't think I introduced  you to my new partner, Michael  Hernandez...
Pleased to meet you, Mr. Shitface...
Eddie folded over his wounded nuts. Hernandez and Taft si on crates to either side. The drugs they've taken from hi are neatly arranged on a garbage can lid.
You have the right to remain silent...  You have the right to an attorney...  You have the right to go back to  Ontario for eight-to-ten on a second  offense...
(in several kinds of  pain) Oh, man, I can't go back in there, I  just can't.
(soothing) 'Course you can't, child, 'course  you can't. That's why you're gonna  start giving us some help.
A pleasant, Santa Monica neighborhood. Spanish style hous

Pleasant, tasteful. Elias's wife, NANCY, (dressed like th attorney she is) sits in an alcove-study reading a real e contract through half-glasses. Elias himself is helping h daughter, MIRANDA, 7, with her homework. He is 38, with t body and bearing of a powerful man.
Again. Three times four.
Seven.
Elias is not a sweet Daddy. It should make us uncomfortab to watch him push his daughter.
No. You're adding again, you have to  multiply. Three and four is seven.  Three times four is...
Twelve.
Three times five.
The DOORBELL.
Can you get that?
Eight.
(getting up; more  about the answer  than the door) Damn it.
Why can't I just use a calculator?

Three men: FELIX BARBOSA (whose photo we saw in Carver's  office). Barbosa is a veteran of the coke business, but h doing too much of the drug now; he's sweating, paranoid,  unstable. With him is GOPHER, early 60s, a wizened high-v old con who Barbosa keeps the way Spanish kings kept dwar for amusement and luck; like the court jester, Gopher can say anything he wants without fear. Behind them is an His kid, CHINO, 17, a thug. Elias knows them all, but is not happy to see them at his door.
What are you doing here?
We've got a problem, David.
Call me on the phone.
Your friend Eddie just started bending  over for the cops.
This is very bad news. Elias murmurs a shaken, "Shit..." steps outside, half-closing the door behind him.
(continuing) They busted him, and he's dealing to  save his ass.
Which is how he'll lose the skinny  little thing.
Did he give us up?
Not yet, but he will if he has to,  and eventually he'll have to.
Daddy! I thought we were doing my  homework.
I don't think he'd talk about us.  He'd try not to.
If we whack him, he definitely won't.
Daddy!!
(to Miranda) Just a second. (to Barbosa) Not yet. Let me check on this, first.
(taunting) Nobody said you had to do the dirty  work, David. I'll take care of --
Felix, if he's a problem, we'll kill  him. I'll kill him myself.

He doesn't realize until it's too late that Nancy has jus then opened the front door to see where he went. They loo at each other, a terrible moment: she knows what he does, hates it, can't bring herself to leave him, hates herself for that.
(continuing) Nancy, get out of here.
For you; it's Eddie.
She hands him a cordless phone, goes inside closing the d
You got a tasty wife, David. No wonder  you don't want us coming here.
(warning him) Don't talk about her that way.
Barbosa laughs.
He can't help it, David, it's his  nature.
(into phone, chipper) Eddie... Sure, man, what do you need?
Elias joins Eddie and Hull to one side. In the b.g. two g sparring.
David, this is John, John, David.  Eddie, this is Eddie. Everybody ready?
(to Elias) So what's this, you want to meet me?
(charming, touch of  mockery) I like to know the important  customers.
Hull makes a show of weary patience, gestures: here I am.
(continuing) You're taking a lot of weight for a  guy we hardly know. Where're you  moving this stuff, John? We haven't  seen you around. We like to have a  sense who your customers are.
Ah, come on, man, do Macy's tell the  Gimbel motherfuckers?
(beat; watches him) Eddie, forget this guy, he's a cop.
He gets up, walks away.
He's blown it. He's been made. The crushing failure. He  rallies himself to indignation.
What is this shit, Eddie? I thought  you were the man.
Eddie's sickened, wants to get paid, owes Taft a bust.
Nobody's the fuckin' man. Go to your  place. I'll call you.
Taft and Hernandez, watching the gym. Hull comes out, loo up and down the street carefully. Taft sits up, pays  attention.
This is our collar?
Hernandez grunts.
(continuing) Who is he?
Some scumbag...

But Taft clearly thinks there's something different about Hull. He's not sure what, but it troubles him. (NOTE: Hul makes a little move that Taft will later realize was a co move. For now he can't quite place it.)
Eddie pleading his case to Elias.
He's no cop, David. He's an animal.  You see his eyes? You never see a  cop with those eyes. I know this  shit, man, you don't.
(giving him an opening) What's going on, Eddie?
Twenty-six thousand cash is what. We  need it, David. We're behind.
Elias studies Eddie: is he a rat? Elias hopes not, but he going to find out. He hands a fat Federal Express envelop through the window.
(a warning) I want him to get it all, Eddie.
Eddie bows in gratitude, hurries off.
Hull's unlocking his door when Belinda, the hooker across the hall, comes out to talk. Her 6-year-old, James, watch silent.
(a crackhead) Mr. Hull... Mr. Hull...
(wearily) What's happening, Belinda?

Now you know, Mr. Hull, I was to the  welfare this afternoon, but the bus,  you know what I'm saying?... the one  bus, and then the other, and when I  got there they'd gone and changed  the time on me, without notification.  They's supposed to give notification,  ain't they? They said I got a thing  in the mail, but I don't remember, I  don't think they sent it, so now I'm  off the welfare, plus I forgot to  take James for his shot... for the  school? Which otherwise they let him  go. And he's gotta learn, he's gotta  learn, don't he, Mr. Hull, you tell  him, so's he can better hisself.
Hull slouches in the doorway, fingers to his eyes.
(to James) You had any food today, James?
(disclaiming any need) I had Ding-Dongs.
(sighs, gives him  money) You go to the Mexican place over  there, and get the chicken tostada  or the beef and bean burrito or both.  And a milk.
I don't like milk. I want a --
(an order) You get the milk! And get something  for your mother, too. (to Belinda) What do you want?
Now, Mr. Hull, if you just --
(to James) Two tostadas, two burritos, two milks.
Gives him another bill. The boy runs off.
You now, I look out for my James  best I can, Mr. Hull, but it's hard.  Now you like the boy, don't you?
Hull grunts.
(continuing) I know you do. And I was thinkin' if  you wanted to take care of him, that  might be good for him. Give him a  male figure to look up to.
Look, Belinda, I can't...
If you could just give me something  for him. Say five thousand dollars... (off Hull's shock) Or maybe four thousand. I couldn't  give up my boy for less than four  thousand...
Hull is rescued from this horror by the ringing PAY PHONE He runs down the hall, grabs it.
It's me. I'm here... Where?... five  minutes.
He dashes past Belinda into his room.

That's what killing Ivy did. I'll  get to him soon.
Carver's impressed.
(continuing) Is that it?
(seeing him to the  door) I want you to get a new apartment.  Something expensive.
I like where I am.
That shithole? You're big time now.  Act it. And get some clothes. Spend  money. Have fun. That's an order.
Hull in a new, expensive suit, gives the big Blonde Woman cash.

Whether I'm here or not, no one else  uses that room. And change the linen  twice a week, just like now. (starts to go, stops,  more money) And make sure James gets what he  needs. And something for you.
He adds another bill. She smiles.

Views, open space, expensive furnishings. Hull (in anothe fancy suit) is hanging a couple of Betty's masks. He's  meticulous about their placement. Elias wanders out from the other rooms, looking around.
(impressed, envious) Nice place. Nice suit.
Hull has a moment of self-consciousness about the suit, c himself out in a mirror -- a private moment. Elias flops on a couch, puts his feet on an antique coffe table.
Hey...!
He hurries over, lifts Elias feet to the floor. Hull brus the wood, inspects it carefully, fusses, worries... Elias amused.
You pick all this shit out yourself?
A Jewish lady in the store helped  me.
(mock touched by racial  harmony) Aw... Very nice. Understated. I'm  impressed.
Hull starts to place stacks of cash in a briefcase. He's  momentarily mesmerized by all the money.
(to himself) Fifty bucks, fifty fucking bucks...
You sold it all?
Hull nods.
(continuing) I'll order a couple more keys from  Barbosa.
Order ten.
Ten??
Better twenty.
(afraid of that) I don't want to push it.
I do. We've got a bigger territory,  we need more product. I want to deal  directly with Gallegos. It would  save us money.
Barbosa'll never let us near him.
Hull closes the briefcase, ushers Elias toward the door.  He's going out, too.
If we buy twenty, Gallegos'll come  to us himself.
How do you know?
When I bought a key from Eddie, you  came to me.
Elias laughs, surprised, afraid.
(continuing) Who's above Gallegos?
Guzman, but he's... Don't ask so  many questions.
How else will I learn? (hint of a threat) Call Barbosa, David, put in our  order... Because we have to split  this, and there isn't enough here  for both of us.
Elias feels the threat.
Despite the CLOSED sign, a light's on inside. Hull knocks No response. He keeps knocking without let-up until:
(annoyed) Nobody's home, go away.
He knocks harder. Finally she appears in the doorway, sto short when she sees it's him. She's immediately aware of  white streaks on her grey suit. she tries to brush them o
(doesn't want to let  him in) Look, I'm tired, why don't you...
Hull holds up the briefcase. She sighs, unlocks the door.
A bill counter toting up the cash. She watches it fixedly avoid looking at him, but she feels the chemistry.
Why do you look at me like that?
How do I look at you?
Like you know something I don't.  Like you're better than me.
That catches Hull off-guard, and he responds with a cando she didn't expect.
I don't think I'm better than you. I  don't think I'm better than anybody.
She's startled by this remark and instinctively drawn to  him.
(continuing) But I do know something... You can't  stop thinking about me.

Embarrassed, she looks away. He takes her hand, and at hi touch something yields to her. She lets him draw her to h His kiss is strangely tender, searching. It turns Betty o incredibly. She melts into him.
Let's go back here...
She leads him into...
She's sweet and loving, but her sweetness scares her. He' all over her, but she pulls back for a moment. There is a couch and before it a coffee table with coke scattered on plate.
(indicates coke) Do this... do it with me.
She offers him a straw. He doesn't take it.
(continuing) This is where I'm at. You want to be  with me, it's gotta be there.
I don't do that.
Never have, never will.
It's for fuck-ups.
What do you think, you're not a  nigger? You're a nigger as much as  me.
More.
She's angry, hurt, confused, wants to love him, but feels won't let her, or she won't let herself. It's torment. Fi she's released by a KNOCK on the door. She goes out to...
Lets in Elias. He smells the tension.
(amused, jealous) Having fun? (neither answers; to  Hull) I talked to Barbosa. He'll see us  now.
Hull turns to Betty. Both want to go that way instead of  this, but events are leading somewhere else. He follows E out.
MUSIC pouring into the darkness.
Kids dancing to a live STAGE ACT. High in a wall: a lit  window.

Very different from the club. A comfortable room with a b tables, filled with men much older than the dancers below Barbosa and Gopher at the bar with Elias and Hull. Chino other SHADOWY FIGURES lurk in the room's depths.
Ten kilos? You're always late on  two.
Not ten... twenty.
Barbosa's impressed.
(continuing) The more we have, the more we can  move. There're markets we can't open  because we don't have the inventory.
Barbosa's coked to the eyeballs, mean and dangerous.
Finally some balls on this team... (taunting Elias) Come work for me, John. I'll give  you your own franchise. You can supply  Elias, lean on him when he's late.
Go fuck yourself.
Barbosa laughs.
I'm with David.
Why? He give you his "designer drugs"  pitch. He's never going to do it.  He's a shmuck.
Don't talk to me that way.
I'm not talking to you at all. I'm  talking to John.
It's the cocaine. Don't listen to  him. Felix, you've had enough...
Shmuck.
Elias goes for him. He's fast and strong, and it takes Ch and Hull to pull him off.
Praise God they don't let guns in  here.
"None of that in here..." "Take it  outside..."
Barbosa's laughing, but his cheek is flecked with his own blood, and his eyes are dead.
David, you've been working out, you're  getting strong. Are you quick, too? (shadow boxes) Come on, I'll give you a shot at me.
Any time, any place.
Right here, right now. Do this.
He puts his hands out, palms up.
This? What is this?
You know, you slap me, I slap you. (mimes that game) Come on, it's fun. Like summer camp.
It doesn't look fun. Elias glances at Hull for guidance.
Don't waste your time.
Stay out of this. (to Elias) Come on, you can do it, David, you're  not a shmuck.
Elias puts his hands out, palms up. Barbosa covers them w his own. ON THE HANDS: Barbosa's broad, muscular with thi gold rings and a Rolex; Elias's paler, slighter, a weddin band and a slim watch.
(continuing) Slap my hands. Just slap them.

Elias looks Barbosa in the eye. He's trying to be a snake but he's more the mouse. He looks away and as he does tri to... Slap him with both hands but hits only... Air. The room breathes. Barbosa turns his rings so the bi surfaces point down.
(continuing) Now it's my turn.
It's Barbosa's turn. He's gonna kill  the white boy.
One more.
No, you went, Davey, now it's my  turn. First to four wins, like the  World Series.
Elias covers Barbosa's palms with his own.
Oh, God, I can't look.
ON THE HANDS: Barbosa tenses his hands. Elias yanks back. Barbosa's hands haven't moved.
You remember the rules? If you flinch,  I get to hit you.
He slaps Elias across the face. Hull starts forward. A kn appears. He stops.
(continuing) Again, shmuck.
Elias covers Barbosa's hands. Barbosa tenses. Elias holds firm, and Barbosa quickly slaps both hands, hard. Elias  doubles over, holding his hands in pain.
One.
That was two.
No, this is two.
He slaps him again, a stinging crack. Elias looks to Hull but they're across a canyon. Hull lowers his eyes.
Oh, and it hurts. Mercy, it hurts.

ON THE HANDS. Barbosa moves his hands a millimeter, and E flinches again. Barbosa smacks him across the face. The s reverberates through the room. Now even Gopher is silent. Tears run from Elias's eyes, blood from his mouth, but he doesn't move.
(continuing) Three.
Felix! No mas. Finito.
steps forward out of the shadows. He is young, mid-30's,  handsome, European features, beautifully dressed, accompa by a guard we'll know as MOLTO. Someone murmurs to someon else:
Gallegos...
Hull reacts. Their eyes meet.
The fight is over! The Ambassador  from the South has spoken!
(refusing any mercy) One more.
Barbosa shakes his head, ashamed now in front of Gallegos
(continuing) One more! We're not finished! (people are silent) Four was the match.
He holds out his hands. Barbosa resumes the stance, then  waits, waits, waits, and finally brings both hands down,  terribly hard, the sound of the slap is awful.
Four.
Okay, that's it. Get away.
Hull leads Elias to the door right past Gallegos. Their g meet again. As they go out they hear Gallegos BERATING Ba in furious Spanish.
Trembling, Elias holds his bloody hands against his chest as Hull leads him in silence down the steps.
Look at me. Look at me, damn it!
He barely whispers, but it's like a shout. Hull, who'd be avoiding his gaze, forces himself to look. Elias's humili is so profound it almost ennobles him. Finally:
Why did you do it?

I needed it. They taught me what I  needed to know. That I'm not part of  them, and I never will be. That they  don't respect me. That I don't deserve  respect. Because I'm a shmuck, John.  I'm a shmuck...
He laughs a terrible laugh. The door behind them opens, a Barbosa appears with Gopher. Everyone is ready for death, but:
David, I'm sorry. It's a crazy time,  and... you know... I'm doing a little  too much coca... I'll buy your kid a  pony... anything you want... Let's  forget about it.

He comes down the stairs, offers his hand. Elias will nev forget about it, but he silently takes the hand, holds th in his own bloody paws, looking directly into Barbosa's f Barbosa becomes uneasy, manages to extract his hand. Elia and Hull continue down and out the door. Gopher gushes to Barbosa.
I am so proud of you. You can be  cruel, and you can be kind. And just  now you were kind. Proud, proud, and  more proud. That's me.
Shut up.
Barbosa, Gopher with Hernandez, Taft's partner. Now we kn Hernandez is corrupt: that's how they knew Eddie was talk
I got nothing to give you, my man.  I'm an il-liquid son of a bitch.
Felix, I keep telling them, "I have  informants down there, I'm working  guys, I can't say who..." If you  don't have money, give me busts, or  they're gonna start wondering about  me.
They're already wondering.
(deadpan) You can have Gopher.
Oh Gawd...
How about a lawyer?
(knows who he means) Felix, don't do this.
(he knows, too) Great, lawyers are great, Jewish is  best. But I need spades, too. The  politicians want dark facts to scare  the suburbs so they'll vote  Republican.
Lawyers and spades; I got the  trifecta: two dealers and a girl who  does their wash. Two niggers and a  kike; all Democrats.
You're my man. And afterwards...
Hernandez rubs thumb against fingers.
When this is over, I'll send you to  Hawaii, Maui. It's very beautiful in  Maui, it's a very spiritual place.
I just want money.
And he's gone.
I wouldn't trust that man when he's  out of rifle range.
Barbosa looks tired.
(continuing;  premonition of  disaster) Don't do this, Felix. It'll go wrong.  Kill Elias if you have to, honey,  but don't set him up for this. It  damages your prestige.
Barbosa faces his cocaine. He tries to resist the pull, t yields. He does another line. It's his friend. He loves i He picks up a cellular phone, dials.

David, you're awake, I'm impressed...  I'm sorry about what happened...  Listen, I'll get you twenty boxes,  like you wanted. You were right, you  should have what you need... Tomorrow  night... Bring your partner and that  girl with the store, Betty... I need  her advice on something. I want us  to have fun, like we used to. We'll  go to that shrimp place, okay?...  Good... Me, too, David. (hangs up; does another  line; drawing it  deep into him) Yes!
Hull jacked up, excited, pleased with himself. As he pace Carver observes his beautiful suit, shoes, expensive watc He looks much better than Carver.
We're getting twenty kilograms  tomorrow. (notes the lightening  sky) Tonight. I made it happen. I pushed  Elias, now he doesn't make a move  without me.
You run Elias.
I control him. Barbosa's selling it  to us because he thinks I can move  it... (now the big news) And last night I met Ramon Gallegos.
Carver sits up fast. Hull likes that.

(continuing) We're getting the dope from him;  it's still coming through Barbosa,  but Gallegos will approach me soon  on his own. We're going to get him,  Gerry. We're going to bring him and  the whole thing down.
Carver sits back, grimaces.
(continuing) What's your problem?
(looking out window) My problem? My problem is that you  don't really know what's happening.
(sardonic) Oh, so, tell me what's happening,  Gerry.
Barbosa is setting you up tonight.
Bullshit.
He's dealing you to Taft and  Hernandez. You're going to be taken  down as you receive the drugs. They're  putting together the arrest team  right now.
That rocks Hull. He is up, pacing.
What do we do?
You stay away. We're going to take  them down.
Who? Elias and Betty? Don't be silly.
My boss wants a bust right now. He  goes before the oversight committee  next week. He needs something to  justify the budget.
(imploring) I'll get him something. Give me ten  days, and I'll get him Gallegos on a  plate.
Too late. The whole thing's set up.
Gerry, what are you telling me? I  need Elias... and Betty. You arrest  them, and you're throwing away  everything I've set up.
It's out of my hands.
Hull walks out.
(continuing) John, don't go near that bust.

location: 96TH STREET NEAR THE AIRPORT/INT. A CAR

text: Elias (no sleep) driving. Betty in front. Hull in back.
We shouldn't go to them. Maybe them  come to us.
He wouldn't.
They pull into the lot of a boarded up restaurant where  Barbosa and Chino stand outside of a limousine.
Taft and Hernandez in the same van that was outside the g earlier. They're watching THROUGH BINOCULARS, night scope They spot Elias's car.
(whispering into radio) Here they are. Nobody move until we  see the green suitcase.
The two groups meeting. Barbosa gives Betty a courtly kis
(flirtatious) I'm sorry for dragging you out so  late, but I have to be careful.
It gives me confidence.
watching planes descend into the airport, nervous. He kno what's coming, but how does he handle it?
Let's see what we've got.
Elias takes a satchel out of the rent-a-car trunk. Chino  opens the limousine's trunk. Inside is an over-sized day- green plastic suitcase. He is about to pick it up.
(continuing; spotting  the police van in  the adjacent lot) Don't touch it.
Everyone looks at him, then the direction he's looking.
What is this?
Something's wrong. What's that van  doing there?
Everyone looks. They can barely see the van. Hull pulls a gun.
(continuing) This is a bust. The minute we take  the stuff, they'll be over us.
He's crazy, David. I thought you  were the crazy one, but it's him.
Hull puts the gun to Barbosa's head, addresses Chino:
Chino, pick up the suitcase and give  it to Elias. I'll only kill him if  something goes wrong.
Chino moves to pick up the suitcase.
No!!
Everyone looks at Hull amazed, even Chino.
(softly) Fucking A, John...
Okay, everybody in the car.

He throws the money in the limo truck, slams the lid. He' running the show now, and everyone knows it. He's winging it, but confident and strangely calm. Elias, energized by Hull's command, grabs Barbosa and thr him toward the limo.
We have a problem.
Shit! Shit! Shit! (aiming rifle; Hull  in sights) Enough of this...
No!
Hull shepherding everyone into the limo. He glances towar the van. On instinct. He pulls Chino to him.
Chino's head explodes. Betty screams.
(screaming at van) Don't shoot... Don't shoot...
Taft hurling Hernandez against the wall.
Goddam it, what the hell are you  doing?
SIRENS. GUNFIRE. Elias drags Barbosa into the limo. Hull  throws Betty into the front seat. The limo takes off.
Hull driving, Betty up front. Elias with a gun on Barbosa back. Hull slaloms the limo through police GUNFIRE. Windo are blown out. Glass everywhere.
(weeping) I asked for this... I asked for it...  It's my fault...
(calm, eyes on road) Relax. We'll make it.
She looks at him, stunned yet soothed by his certainty.
He's a cop. He has to be. How else  would he have known?
If I was cop, you'd be face down  back there.
How did you know?
The whole thing smelled. Changing  his mind about the stuff. Meeting us  way out here. And I'd seen cops in  that van before. Hernandez is dirty,  that's who he's using.
(to Barbosa) Get out of the car.
He starts to open the door.
David, not now.
Yes, now!
Racing. Taft at wheel, raging at Hernandez.
Who are you, man? Who the fuck are  you?
(stonewalling) I'm me.

He traded us to the cops. Just like  Eddie. Eddie, who was nice to my  daughter, had to die because that's  the rule. And you were vulgar about  my wife, Felix, so at the very least  the same rule applies to you.
I'll give you money. I'll give you a  million. Anything you want.
I want you to get out of the car.  Get out of the fucking car. Out of  the fucking --
(near tears) No, no... we can't do this.
(turning around from  front seat) Stop it, David, or we're...
Elias wheels on him, sticks the gun in his face:
(in a fury) Look at my hands!
He holds them up: swollen, black and blue, cut up.
(continuing; to  Barbosa, softly) Get out of the car.
Barbosa's frozen. Elias grabs his hand, SHOOTS a bullet  through. Barbosa screams...
No!
Goddammit!
Elias wheels on them, swinging the gun from one to the ot
Stay out of this, or you'll die.  You'll both die. Everyone'll die.
His fury makes anything seem possible. He pushes open the door. Trembling, Barbosa starts to climb out. The limo enters a tunnel, police still in pursuit. Halfway out, Barbosa stops.
I can't...

Elias SHOOTS him in the butt. He shrieks, jerks forward. cops are getting close behind. Other cops waiting at the far end of the tunnel. Hull hits the brakes, spins a 180 into the opposite lane. Barbosa is flung out of the car and plastered by a succes of fishtailing vehicles. Hull speeds back the other way. They're going straight at
Taft and Hull, the two drivers, lock eyes. It's chicken, more than that. Two men set against each other who, for s reason, want to be friends. At the last instant, the van swerves away, but:
Taft sees the gun too late. He can do nothing. Hull's gaze follows Taft's. He sees Elias, deliberately  swerves, sending the SHOT wild.
I had him!
You want to kill a cop?? Don't be  stupid.
The limo speeds away.
The windows shot out. Hull and Betty silent, shaken. Elia charged up, happy.
Everything is different. We're the  Colombians now. (radiant) This is the greatest night of my  life. Terrible but great. Felix was  right...
(appalled) About what?
He said I should kill a man. He was  right.
My God.
Barbosa was a roach. Do you miss  him? Will anybody in the world miss  him?
Are you a roach, too?
(happily) Yes. Thank God.
(to Hull) What about you?
He's silent, keeps driving. She's had enough.
(continuing) Stop the car.
Hull looks at her.
(continuing) Stop it!
He brakes to a stop. She jumps out, leans back in.
(continuing) No more laundering, no more anything.  I'm finished with this.
And she disappears into the night. Elias watches her go.  Hull resumes driving.
She knows too much. We have to kill  her.
No! She's with me. She's not going  to talk. (looks at Elias) You touch her, I'll kill you.
She's your responsibility then.
Hull accepts it.

(continuing) We're going to get the money now,  John. Enough for the new drug. We're  going to be rich. We're going to be  so rich that we're going to leave  the world of ordinary people and  going to a higher realm. I mean that.
They're going to come after us.
(matter-of-fact) It's a hardball game. We're hardball  players.

Hernandez comes out of a bodega with groceries, wine and woman. He nuzzles her as he lets her into his car. As he' getting behind the wheel, Molto (Gallegos' guard) stops t door from closing. The conversation is entirely in SPANIS
It wasn't my fault.
It never is.
He SHOOTS him in the head. Hernandez slumps against the w The woman screams. Molto walks away.
Hull finds a door, pushes the buzzer. Betty looks through the glass. She's afraid of him.
Don't kill me. I'm not going to talk.  I swear. Please.
Then she looks closer and sees not murder in his face, bu need. She opens the door. Without a word, he gathers her him. She can't resist him now. Her mouth is everywhere on him.
Betty gasping in the wake of pleasure, turning her face a from him, she feels so exposed.
Don't look...
She hides her face in his neck.
They lie in each other's arms, relaxed together for the f time. A wonderful, unprotected openness.
(softly) Tell me about you.
(half-kidding) Everything worth knowing you just  found you.
He laughs. They begin to make love again. Suddenly: AN EX HAND stroking Betty's hair. She gasps. A gun in Hull's ea Another in her face. Guns all around.
Don't hurt her.
Hands pull him out of bed, leave her there alone. We see  Molto, two or three others.

RAMON GALLEGOS lays a bouquet of white lillies on a grave He kneels, whispers a prayer, crosses himself. He rises and walks to where Molto and the other guards ho Hull and Elias. Gallegos is in his thirties, more Europea than Barbosa. He has a distinctly mild manner.
Who's grave?
An impudent question, but Elias seems strangely bright-ey despite the guns held on him.

My wife's. She died of leukemia three  years ago. (looks around) I like to be among the dead. They  never interrupt you. (turning to them) Felix Barbosa started out as a skinny  fourteen-year-old fucking Yankee  businessman in Bogata hotels. He  grew up. He made himself strong and  rich, but getting there made him  sick, and that killed him. So he  lost everything for the same reason  he'd gotten it in the first place.  Now we'll see if you can do as well.
A PRIEST going by greets Gallegos who responds warmly. Th chat a minute in SPANISH. The Priest leaves.
(continuing) Felix owed me one million eight  hundred thousand dollars.
He addresses this to Hull; Elias feels left out.
(continuing) When you killed him, you bought the  debt; now you owe it to me; you get  to keep thirty percent, like he did.  You have three days.
Gallegos turns to leave.
Who did Barbosa collect from?
If you don't know, you shouldn't  have killed him.
He notices Hull's earring: two tiny dice, the spots made minuscule jewels. Unembarrassed, he fingers it.
(continuing) Cute... Can I have that?
Without waiting for an answer, he yanks it out of Hull's and walks away, leaving Hull bleeding through his fingers before a stone cross.
A club on the corner. THROUGH A WINDOW we see a RAP ACT o the stage, their MUSIC pumping out onto the street. Hull  pulls up in a Jaguar. He and Elias go through a door adja to the club.
The MUSIC is still audible here, though muffled. Elias an Hull are pushing at door Gopher is trying to hold closed.
I don't want you in here. You killed  the man, and I loved him. I don't  want to have anything to do with  you.
Elias kicks it open, and they enter Gopher's tiny, misera domain. He's wearing some sort of negligee and an immense naked woman fills his bed. We still hear the MUFFLED MUSI
(continuing; apoplectic) I'm a sixty-three-year-old man! I'm  a grandfather! Would you hit a sixty- three-year-old white man? Would you  hit your own grandfather?
(slaps him against  wall) Listen, you fucking monkey, you know  who owed him money, and we know you  know. Tell us or --
Hull pulls him off. Elias is angry. They struggle.
He'll tell us. Gopher, just...
Meaning: deal with me or deal with Elias.
You can't tell anyone it was me.
The MUSIC continues OVER the following sequence:
Elias arguing with a dealer. He slaps him around.
Money is exchanged. The money is stuffed in a satchel.

A well-dressed lawyer (30's) talking with clients, a  distinguished couple in their 60's. The door BANGS open and a secretary is unable to restrain Hull and Elias as they charge into the room. The lawyer i up on his feet, but Hull shoves him around as Elias polit explains to the clients that this will only take a moment
Hull's hands thrust more money in. It's getting full.
A biker in leathers on hands-and-knees spitting blood ont the cement floor. Hull stands over him, fists clenched.
A satchel stuffed with money is latched, set next to anot latched one. A third is opened, money and jewelry dumped
Hull looking into the trunk. Elias is beat.
Where the hell is all the money?  We're still a million short.
I gotta get laid.
David, we've got thirty-six hours.
(slams trunk, moves  toward door) Pick me up at Jacqueline's in the  morning.
Sooner than that.
Elias gets in the car and drives off. Hull turns and a da American sedan pulls up alongside. Carver behind the whee
(an order) Get in.
(as he gets in) What are you doing here? You're going  to get me killed.
Carver peels away fast. He's very angry, frightened, too, but that's hidden.
Where the hell have you been?
Doing my job.
There's an indifference to Carver's authority we haven't  heard before. Hull isn't even aware of it, but Carver is.

You violated a direct order to stay  away from that bust. As a result, a  police informant is dead, a state  senator was critically injured in  the tunnel pile up and a city  policeman was subsequently murdered.
I didn't blow my cover.
Don't get smart with me, motherfucker.

Don't be a shmuck, Gerry. I'm talking  to Gallegos. I'm collecting his money.  We can set him up right now. (NOTE: Carver arrives  somewhere and parks.  To be discussed, but  let's say, for now,  that we are:)
They get out of the car. Carver takes out a flask, has a  drink, offers it to Hull who declines.
Never have, never will. (puts the flask away) I want you to give me your gun. You're  coming in right now.
(doesn't understand) Coming in where?
Your assignment has been terminated.  You're not going out there again. If  I have to, I'll put you in custody.
(uncomprehending) I'm going to have Gallegos in two  days.
Carver says nothing. Suddenly Hull understands.
(continuing) You're protecting him. You're  protecting Gallegos.
Carver snorts: ridiculous.

(continuing) No, of course. That's why you wanted  to bust Elias and Betty. I was getting  close, and you wanted to cut this  off then... What is he, the new  Noriega? Helps you fight commies, so  you let him sell drugs to the niggers.  Two birds with one stone.
You violated orders, so you're  through. Don't make a conspiracy  theory out of it.
(laughs) I'm through...? Then, I might as  well have a drink after all.
Surprised, Carver reaches for the flask. As he does, Hull grabs him, pushes him out over the edge of the building,  holds him there.
(continuing) Now tell me the truth or they're  going to decide your troubles got  the best of you.
Carver struggles. Hull pushes him out farther. Carver dan
You're insane.
All the more reason to do what I  say. Jesus, Ger, I'm having trouble  holding on...
All right!
Say it!
It's the State Department.
Hull pulls him back in. Carver slumps against the wall, d greedily. Hull lets him for a moment, then takes the flas away.
(continuing) I told you, Gallegos's uncle is a  big deal down there.
Guzman.
